text:
My parents always
told us growing up

that we have three senses in
our family: a sense of self,

a sense of community,
and a sense of humor.

And I wanted to bring
all three of those senses
to bear on the stage for HBS.

You can learn a new way of being
from every person you encounter.

And what better place to start
thinking about your leadership

qualities than what you've
learned from your own family.

My dad was the most
self-actualized person
I've ever met.

For me, the leadership
lesson from him

was deeply knowing yourself will
make you a much better leader
and a much better manager.

My mom, she can get along
with anyone, anywhere,
from any place at any time.

My oldest sister Alix is
open to the world in ways

that I had never
considered before.

And then my sister
Casey, anything

that passes through her lens
of what is right and wrong
has a clear answer.

I went to University of Virginia
for college as a history major.

I joined McKinsey
right after school.

And so in many ways,
I had the crash course

of business knowledge on
the job in the real world.

During my time at
McKinsey, I learned

what I would call a
very specific language
for problem solving.

You're always learning
a new language.

And that's both the
actual words you

use and your exposure
to concepts and ideas

that you weren't
exposed to before.

I then joined a startup and
learned another language,

and I wanted to come to HBS to
learn yet another one so I could

bring the textbook
knowledge of business

and a really solid foundational
knowledge to any problem
that I face going forward.

The experience of sitting
and listening and thinking

very intently is something I
want to take with me forever,

that my opinion is
maybe not the most
important thing in the room.

My ability to hear other people
fully, to listen intently,

and to hopefully
synthesize something that's

smarter than I could have
come up with on my own, that's

the skill set that I think
HBS has demonstrated for me.

Several classes and several
class sessions in particular

have really stuck with
me as clarifying moments

in the type of
leader I want to be.

One was a January term, The
Spiritual Lives of Leaders.

That class expanded my
mind in a number of ways

and really opened me
up to faith traditions
that I didn't know about.

And there was one class
session in particular

where Ned Friedman, the
president of the Arnold

Arboretum, came to speak
to us, and he gave an hour
long presentation about trees.

And his thesis to
us was, you should

visit the Arboretum in the
winter, and I'll show you why.

So that class, I think,
has changed my life.

I think my eyes are
open in a different way.

When I graduate, I'm moving
back to New York City.

I'll work there for the summer,
getting a really deep experience
in the restaurant industry.

Then I'll return to McKinsey and
build out my managerial toolkit.

And eventually, I'd like to open
my own restaurant in Brooklyn,

serving mostly plant
based delicious food.

Just like many of my classmates,
I'm figuring it out every day.

And part of the joy,
I think, of post-HBS

will be that we
have so many more

people to lean on to help
us make the big decisions

and stay true to what
we actually want to do.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
